Help.Tip: Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
Help.Text:
mclinv - PROCESSDEFAULTS
Menu allowing user choice of stored parameter defaults.
 
 Default = SYSTEM
 Allowed = SYSTEM
 Allowed = PROJECT
 Allowed = USER
 SYSTEM defaults are the defaults listed in the CPS documentation.
 
 PROJECT defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as Project
 Default button.
 
 USER defaults are defaults the user has saved via the Save as User Default
 button.

Help.Tip: Output products: 1, 2, 3, 4 inversions; 0, -1, -2 QC displays.
Help.Text:
mclinv - OPT_OUTPUT
Output products: 1, 2, 3, 4 inversions; 0, -1, -2 QC displays.
 
 Default = 2
 Allowed =  1   RS and DRHO;                           2-parameter inversion.
 Allowed =  2   ZS and RHO;                 INTEGRATED 2-parameter inversion.
 Allowed =  3   pseudo-RS;                             1-parameter inversion.
 Allowed =  4   pseudo-ZS;                  INTEGRATED 1-parameter inversion.
 Allowed =  0   (P-wave) Reflection angles;                       QC display.
 Allowed = -1   Coefficient of DRHO for Rps;                      QC display.
 Allowed = -2   Coefficient of DVS for Rps;                       QC display.
 
 If OPT_OUTPUT = 1, output is interface-oriented, consisting of two-trace
 gathers (or 4-trace gathers if OPT_SD_OUT = YES) containing inverted
 contrasts across interfaces of Shear Impedance and Density.
 
 If OPT_OUTPUT = 2, output is layer-oriented, consisting of 2-trace gathers
 (or 4-trace gathers if OPT_SD_OUT = YES) containing band-limited, integrated
 versions of the option 1 products.
 
 If OPT_OUTPUT = 3, output is interface oriented, consisting of single-trace
 gathers (or 2-trace gathers if OPT_SD_OUT = YES) containing inverted
 "pseudo-Shear Reflectivity," defined as the coefficient of -2*sin(theta)
 that best fits the input data, where "theta" is reflection angle on the
 P-wave side.
 
 If OPT_OUTPUT = 4, output is layer-oriented, consisting of single-trace
 gathers (or 2-trace gathers if OPT_SD_OUT = YES) containing inverted
 "pseudo-Shear Impedance;" i.e., a band-limited, integrated version of the
 option 3 product.
 
 If OPT_OUTPUT = 0, -1 or -2, then no inversion is performed and output
 traces are QC products (Output gathers contain the same number of traces
 as the input gathers for these options):
 If OPT_OUTPUT = 0, output traces contain reflection angles (in degrees) at
 each offset and depth according to your specified P and S velocity models
 (reflection angles on the P-wave side, not S-wave side).
 If OPT_OUTPUT = -1, output traces contain coefficients of DZS (from Aki
 & Richards equation for forward modeling of Rps) at each offset & depth.
 If OPT_OUTPUT = -2, output traces contain coefficients of DRHO (from Aki
 & Richards equation for forward modeling of Rps) at each offset & depth.

Help.Tip: Whether to output standard deviations of inverted quantities.
Help.Text:
mclinv - OPT_SD_OUT
Whether to output standard deviations of inverted quantities.
 
 Default = NO
 Allowed = YES - Output standard deviation traces.
 Allowed = NO  - Don't output standard deviation traces.
 
 Setting OPT_SD_OUT = YES doubles the number of output traces by appending
 traces containing estimated standard deviations of the inverted quantities
 to each output gather. For example, if OPT_OUTPUT = 1, MCLINV would normally
 output 2 traces in each gather, containing RS and DRHO in that order.
 If OPT_SD_OUT = YES, then 4 traces are output in each gather, containing:
 
         RS, DRHO, SD(RS), SD(DRHO)
 
 in that order, where SD(x) denotes standard deviation of quantity x.
 
 Standard deviations are only available when DIAG_LOAD > 0, and only when an
 actual inversion is being performed (OPT_OUTPUT > 0).
 
 For integrated inversion outputs (OPT_OUTPUT = 2 and 4), estimated
 standard deviations are those of the corresponding NON-integrated outputs
 (OPT_OUTPUT = 1 and 3, respectively).

Help.Tip: Push for file selection popup for P-wave velocity model file.
Help.Text:
mclinv - SELECT_PATH_VEL_P
Push for file selection popup for P-wave velocity model file.
 
 Push this button for a file selector popup to choose the P-wave velocity
 model file, assuming that the file already exists.  If you prefer, or if
 the file doesn't exist yet, you may simply type the file name into the
 ordinary text box. The default filter in the selection popup includes a
 ".trc" extension, but you may instead choose a velocity model in a .hgrid
 file, or Gocad Voxet file, or even a CPS velocity file (If a CPS velocity
 file, velocities must be of type VZIN).
 
 PATH_VEL_P should be a gridded depth migration velocity model specifying
 the P-wave interval velocity in depth.
 
 MCLINV uses both the P-wave and S-wave velocity models to estimate the
 angles corresponding to each offset, and also to calculate Vp/Vs ratios
 needed in Aki & Richards coefficients.

Help.Tip: Value of NUMTR global upon input, shown for reference.
Help.Text:
mclinv - NUMTR_IN
Value of NUMTR global upon input, shown for reference.
 
 MCLINV requires gathered input; therefore, the NUMTR for your input traces
 must always be at least 2.

Help.Tip: Value of NUMTR global upon output, shown for reference.
Help.Text:
mclinv - NUMTR_OUT
Value of NUMTR global upon output, shown for reference.
 
 Number of traces in each output gather, corresponding to the number of
 output quantities (plus standard deviations of those quantities if
 OPT_SD_OUT=YES). Depending on your choice of OPT_OUTPUT:
 If OPT_OUTPUT = 1 or 2, NUMTR_OUT will be 2 (or 4 if OPT_SD_OUT=YES).
 If OPT_OUTPUT = 3 or 4, NUMTR_OUT will be 1 (or 2 if OPT_SD_OUT=YES).
 If OPT_OUTPUT = 0, -1 or -2, NUMTR_OUT will be the same as NUMTR_IN.

Help.Tip: Source depth, in depth units, assumed constant.
Help.Text:
mclinv - DEP_SRC
Source depth, in depth units, assumed constant.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real < end_trace
 Currently, MCLINV assumes constant source and receiver depths (flat
 recording geometry). This may eventually be generalized to allow topography
 files for source and receiver depths.

Help.Tip: Receiver depth, in depth units, assumed constant.
Help.Text:
mclinv - DEP_REC
Receiver depth, in depth units, assumed constant.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real < end_trace
 Currently, MCLINV assumes constant source and receiver depths (flat
 recording geometry). This may eventually be generalized to allow topography
 files for source and receiver depths.

Help.Tip: Number of internal velocity grid points in X (fast) direction.
Help.Text:
mclinv - NUM_VEL_X
Number of internal velocity grid points in X (fast) direction.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int > 0
 MCLINV stores the P-wave and S-wave velocity values at NUM_VEL_X grid points
 in the X (fast) direction, and then interpolates (bi)linearly to the (X,Y)
 location of each data gather being inverted.
 
 It is intended that velocities vary smoothly, so NUM_VEL_X can be chosen
 considerably smaller than the number of X values in the gridded model used
 for migration. The NUM_VEL_X grid values will cover the same total range of
 X values as in the input velocity model files.
 
 If NUM_VEL_X = 1, then MCLINV will use only averages of the input velocity
 models in the X direction. In this case, conversions between offsets and
 angles for input CIP gathers will not vary laterally in the X direction.

Help.Tip: Number of internal velocity grid points in Y (slow) direction.
Help.Text:
mclinv - NUM_VEL_Y
Number of internal velocity grid points in Y (slow) direction.
 
 Default = 1
 Allowed = int > 0
 MCLINV stores the P-wave and S-wave velocity values at NUM_VEL_Y grid points
 in the Y (slow) direction, and then interpolates (bi)linearly to the (X,Y)
 location of each data gather being inverted.
 
 It is intended that velocities vary smoothly, so NUM_VEL_Y can be chosen
 considerably smaller than the number of Y values in the gridded model used
 for migration. The NUM_VEL_Y grid values will cover the same total range of
 Y values as in the input velocity model files.
 
 If NUM_VEL_Y = 1, then MCLINV will use only averages of the input velocity
 models in the Y direction. In this case, conversions between offsets and
 angles for input CIP gathers will not vary laterally in the Y direction.

Help.Tip: Vertical smoothing, in depth units, to apply to velocity models.
Help.Text:
mclinv - DEP_SMOOTH
Vertical smoothing, in depth units, to apply to velocity models.
 
 Default = 0.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 A running average smoother of this length, in depth units, is applied to
 the P and S velocity models before performing any ray tracing. This may be
 useful if the velocity models used for depth migration include sharp layer
 boundaries.
 
 The default value DEP_SMOOTH = 0.0 does not perform any velocity smoothing
 in the vertical direction.

Help.Tip: Depth interval corresponding to one "second" in traces.
Help.Text:
mclinv - DEP_SCALE
Depth interval corresponding to one "second" in traces.
 
 Default = 1000.0
 Allowed = real > 0.0
 This parameter is provided for compatibility with other depth processes
 such as KMIG. However, you really ought to take the default value (1000),
 since any other value is incompatible with Cbyt.

Help.Tip: Maximum incidence angle to consider in input, in degrees.
Help.Text:
mclinv - ANG_MAX
Maximum incidence angle to consider in input, in degrees.
 
 Default = 60.0
 Allowed = 90.0 > real > 0.0
 All events in your input data regarded as having an incident (P-wave) angle
 at the reflector greater than ANG_MAX will be ignored. Here, reflection
 angles of events are estimated from reflector depth, P and S velocities,
 offset, and source and receiver depths.
 
 You should have a very large angle range, possibly greater than the
 default ANG_MAX = 60, if you are doing 2-parameter inversion (OPT_OUTPUT =
 1 or 2) and you hope to obtain a reasonable inversion for density. Use a
 smaller ANG_MAX, e.g., 50 or less, if you are only doing 1-parameter
 inversion (OPT_OUTPUT = 3 or 4).

Help.Tip: Scale factor to convert trace amplitudes to reflection coefficients.
Help.Text:
mclinv - AMP_SCALE
Scale factor to convert trace amplitudes to reflection coefficients.
 
 Default = 1.0
 Allowed = real /= 0.0
 If you know the scale factor that will convert your input trace amplitudes
 to true reflectivity, setting this parameter will produce output with a
 more accurate amplitude scale. Otherwise, the output products will have an
 arbitrary scale.
 
 You may set AMP_SCALE negative if you think your data has reversed polarity.

Help.Tip: Minimum # of live trace samples at any depth to attempt inversion.
Help.Text:
mclinv - FOLD_MIN
Minimum # of live trace samples at any depth to attempt inversion.
 
 Default = 2
 Allowed = int >= num_parms (where num_parms = # of parameters to invert for:
 2 parameters if OPT_OUTPUT = 1 or 2,  1 parameter if OPT_OUTPUT = 3 or 4).
 At each depth level, MCLINV will not attempt inversion unless the input
 gather contains at least this many live trace samples at that depth.

Help.Tip: Diagonal load, in percent, for inverse calculations.
Help.Text:
mclinv - DIAG_LOAD
Diagonal load, in percent, for inverse calculations.
 
 Default = 5.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 Given noisy data, the diagonal load factor stabilizes the inversion.
 Theoretically, if the signal/noise ratio in your data is S/N (expressed in
 terms of energies, not amplitudes), the diagonal load should be chosen as:
 
                   DIAG_LOAD  =  100 / (S/N)
 
 which is simply the noise/signal ratio (multiplied by 100 because diagonal
 load is expressed as a percentage).

Help.Tip: Max wavelength to keep in integrated output (OPT_OUTPUT = 2 or 4).
Help.Text:
mclinv - WAVLEN_MAX
Max wavelength to keep in integrated output (OPT_OUTPUT = 2 or 4).
 
 Default = 500.0
 Allowed = real >= 0.0
 The integration step in options 2 and 4 can introduce spurious low frequency
 (long wavelength) energy outside the bandwidth of the seismic data. The
 WAVLEN_MAX parameter removes this noise after integration by eliminating
 energy with wavelengths longer than WAVLEN_MAX (measured in depth units).
 In practice, this is implemented by applying a running average smoother of
 length WAVLEN_MAX to each integrated depth trace, and then subtracting the
 smoothed trace from unsmoothed trace.
 
 If WAVLEN_MAX = 0.0, then no long wavelength energy is removed from the
 integrated traces.
 
 Active only when OPT_OUTPUT = 2 or 4.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                         C P S   P R O C E S S
 
 Name       : MCLINV   (Mode Converted Linearized INVersion)
 Category   : inversion
 Written    : 2002-02-15   by: Bob Baumel
 Revised    : 2006-10-16   by: D. Glover
 Maturity   : production
 Purpose    : Linearized inversion of mode converted P-S reflection data.
 Portability: No known limitations.
 Parallel   : No.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          GENERAL DESCRIPTION
 
 MCLINV is a linearized inversion of mode converted (P-S) seismic data.
 Input traces consist of PRESTACK DEPTH MIGRATED P-S common image point (CIP)
 gathers. Both 2-parameter and 1-parameter inversion options are available.
 In 2-parameter inversion, output consists of 2-trace gathers containing
 inverted Shear Impedance and Density. In 1-parameter inversion, output
 consists of inverted "pseudo-Shear Impedance." Output options include both
 interface-oriented (contrasts across layer boundaries) and layer-oriented
 (bandlimited properties of the layers themselves) quantities. To estimate
 uncertainty of the results, you may output standard deviation traces by
 setting OPT_SD_OUT = YES (This doubles the number of output traces).
 Several additional kinds of QC displays are also available.
 
 
 Inversion Method
 
 MCLINV performs "linearized" inversion in that it's based on a linearized
 approximation (Aki & Richards) of the relationship between angle-dependent
 reflectivity and contrasts in material properties.  Nonlinear effects are
 ignored or treated as known, smoothly varying "background" properties.
 
 In order to obtain the angle-dependent reflectivity to be inverted, offsets
 of the input traces are first converted to (depth-dependent) angles using
 the same P and S velocity models that were used for depth migration. As the
 original source and receiver positions are no longer available after depth
 migration, offsets in each input gather are related to angles using a locally
 plane-layered assumption at each CIP location. Plane-layered ray tracing is
 implemented using the same approximation as in process AVAGRAD (specifically,
 the CURVED RAY, not straight ray, approximation in AVAGRAD). Here, this
 approximation is applied separately to the P-wave and S-wave legs, and a
 transcendental equation must be solved to determine the reflection angles
 for each input trace at each depth (See ALGORITHM_DOC for statement of the
 equation which is solved).
 
 Once the offsets are converted to angles at each depth, angle-dependent
 reflectivity is inverted to rock property contrasts as in process PSLINV.
 A diagonal load term (DIAG_LOAD) is used to stabilize the inversion in the
 presence of noise.
 
 
 Output Products
 
 For OPT_OUTPUT = 1, output consists of contrasts across the interfaces of
 Shear Impedance and Density. As in process PSLINV, these quantities are
 defined as:
 
      "RS"  (="DZS") = 0.5 * d(S-Impedance) / (S-Impedance)
      "DRHO"         = 0.5 * d(Density) / (Density)
 
 For OPT_OUTPUT = 2, output consists of integrated versions of OPT_OUTPUT = 1
 products, representing band-limited values of Shear Impedance and Density
 themselves. As in process PSLINV, the outputs are actually defined as:
 
      "ZS"   = 0.5 * log(S-Impedance)
      "RHO"  = 0.5 * log(Density)
 
 For OPT_OUTPUT = 3, output consists of "pseudo-Shear Reflectivity" which we
 define as the coefficient of -2*sin(theta) which best fits the data (Here,
 "theta" denotes reflection angle on the P-wave side, not S-wave side).
 In principle, "pseudo-Shear Reflectivity" should be approximately the same
 as the Shear Reflectivity when Vp/Vs = 2.
 
 For OPT_OUTPUT = 4, output consists of "pseudo-Shear Impedance;" i.e.,
 a band-limited, integrated version of the OPT_OUTPUT = 3 product. As in
 PSLINV, this is actually defined as:
 
      "pseudo-ZS" = 0.5 * log(pseudo-S-Impedance)
 
 where "pseudo-S-Impedance" should be approximately the same as S-Impedance
 when Vp/Vs = 2.
 
 In all cases, outputs are arbitrarily scaled unless you've set the AMP_SCALE
 factor just right.
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
                          ADVICE FOR USERS
 
 Velocity Model Sampling
 
 As MCLINV makes a locally plane-layered assumption when ray tracing, it is
 assumed that structure isn't overly complex. Therefore, you may not need
 full details of your depth migration velocity models to enable MCLINV's
 conversion of offset to angle (We work with depth migrated data in order to
 facilitate comparison of P-P and P-S data, not necessarily because we're
 trying to handle a structurally complex earth). Parameters NUM_VEL_X and
 NUM_VEL_Y allow resampling the velocity models to a coarse grid laterally.
 If NUM_VEL_X = 1 and NUM_VEL_Y = 1, the velocity models are each averaged
 laterally to produce single P and S velocity functions (similar to choosing
 OPT_AVE = YES in processes AVAST and AVAGRAD). You may also use the
 DEP_SMOOTH parameter to smooth velocities vertically if necessary.
 
 
 Muting of Input Data
 
 Input data should be MUTED (head and tail) to remove noise or any data that
 might be misinterpreted by MCLINV, such as migration artifacts in regions
 where acquisition was less than full fold. Muting is probably done most
 easily while the depth migrated input data is sorted into common offsets,
 rather than the CIP gathers which must actually be input to MCLINV. Use a
 ZERO LENGTH TAPER in MUTE to avoid tapers which MCLINV might interpret as
 spurious AVA behavior.
 
 
 Data Polarity
 
 You may set AMP_SCALE negative if your data haven't been processed to match
 the sign convention of the Aki & Richards P-S reflection coefficients.
 
 
 Standard Deviation Output
 
 If OPT_SD_OUT = YES, traces are output showing estimated standard deviations
 for each inverted quantity at each depth, thereby doubling the number of
 output traces. Estimated standard deviations are based partly on your
 DIAG_LOAD parameter (which implies an estimate of signal-to-noise, see
 advice about diagonal load, below) and partly on the forward modeling
 relationship between rock properties and data.
 
 Standard deviations are only available when DIAG_LOAD > 0, and only when an
 actual inversion is being performed (OPT_OUTPUT > 0).
 
 For integrated inversion outputs (OPT_OUTPUT = 2 and 4), estimated
 standard deviations are those of the corresponding NON-integrated outputs
 (OPT_OUTPUT = 1 and 3, respectively).
 
 
 Other QC Products
 
 If OPT_OUTPUT is zero or negative, MCLINV outputs gathers of the same size
 as it receives. When OPT_OUTPUT = 0, traces are filled with the ANGLES found
 by ray tracing for the current offset, at each depth, according to the input
 P and S velocity models. Computed angles are the reflection angles, in
 degrees, on the P-wave side. This display shows the extent to which you lose
 near angles in the shallow section and far angles in the deep section.
 
 If OPT_OUTPUT = -1, traces are filled with the Aki & Richards coefficients
 of DZS (for forward modeling of Rps) at the computed angles.
 
 If OPT_OUTPUT = -2, traces are filled with the Aki & Richards coefficients
 of DRHO (for forward modeling of Rps) at the computed angles.
 
 Comparison of the option -1 and -2 displays can illustrate whether the
 coefficients of DZS and DRHO are sufficiently independent to invert for two
 parameters at each depth.
 
 
 2-parameter vs. 1-parameter Inversion
 
 You should have a very large angle range, possibly greater than the
 default ANG_MAX = 60, if you are doing 2-parameter inversion (OPT_OUTPUT =
 1 or 2) and you hope to obtain a reasonable inversion for density. Use a
 smaller ANG_MAX, e.g., 50 or less, if you are only doing 1-parameter
 inversion (OPT_OUTPUT = 3 or 4).
 
 
 Choosing Diagonal Load
 
 The diagonal load factor DIAG_LOAD helps to stabilize the inversion in the
 presence of noise. If you can estimate the signal/noise ratio (S/N) in your
 data (expressed in terms of energies, not amplitudes), then a suitable
 diagonal load may be chosen as:
 
                   DIAG_LOAD  =  100 / (S/N)
 
 which is simply the noise/signal ratio (multiplied by 100 because diagonal
 load is expressed as a percentage).
 
 
 Avoiding Spurious Low Frequency Trend
 
 Since MCLINV is a bandlimited inversion process, using only the frequencies
 present in your seismic data, any low frequency (long wavelength) trend
 produced by the integration step when OPT_OUTPUT = 2 or 4 is necessarily
 spurious. (We do not attempt to include a meaningful long wavelength trend
 in our inversion, which would require an interpretive model building process
 using an interactive, workstation-based program.) The WAVLEN_MAX parameter
 removes spurious low frequency energy by eliminating wavelengths longer than
 WAVLEN_MAX following the integration step. This is implemented by applying a
 running average smoother of length WAVLEN_MAX to each integrated depth trace,
 and then subtracting the smoothed trace from the unsmoothed trace.
 
 The WAVLEN_MAX parameter plays the same role as FREQ_MIN in process PSLINV,
 except that because we're working in depth, we express it as a wavelength
 instead of a frequency.
 
 
 Memory Usage Warning
 
 Although MCLINV saves tables at only the X-Y grid specified by NUM_VEL_X and
 NUM_VEL_Y (which may be a fairly coarse grid), your ENTIRE velocity models
 (first P, later S) are nevertheless held in memory briefly while reading the
 models (This temporary memory usage is not reflected in the scratch figure
 printed into the report file). This is due to use of the VELGRID primitive,
 which made it relatively simple to program the velocity model input. If this
 turns out to be a problem, we can reprogram it with other primitive calls to
 avoid having the whole model in memory at once.
